text: This is definitely Marchetta's most sophisticated effort and is quite a heavy issues-based young adult text. Nevertheless, I felt some parts were rather haphazardly thrown together and the whole thing was a bit melodramatic for my tastes.
Was harder to get into for me than her other books, but I was very moved by the end. She is a great storyteller.
interesting mystery.
I liked this book - it kept me interested through the whole thing. There is a bit of swearing.

I don't get the hype, really. I didn't find the characters compelling or interesting. To be totally honest, I thought it was quite predictable. Although I clearly didn't figure out *everything* at the end, I knew from page 5 that the characters in the manuscript were somehow the ones acting in Taylor's history. So, that said, no shock.I thought that there was no reason to care about Taylor. We know little about her for 300 pages, except that she's got mommy fixation. Even in the end, I still didn't care about Taylor nor understand why I should care about her. I felt like the last 100 pages were the best in the book in terms of writing, action, and story. I wish a lot at the start could have been cut OR could have been better fleshed out in terms of character development. I think there were too many characters without any defining features who just became names to me. All of that said, I think this book definitely would have its readers. I think a lot of reluctant readers would have a hard time with this one because it requires reading the whole book. I think it might even require two readings. In terms of writing, Marchetta can paint some nice images for sure. She can also paint quite brutal ones. Sensitive readers might be put off by this one, since it's quite brutal in parts. Alas, the book earns a 3 star because I might, in the future, reread it to see if I missed something. If a book I don't care for a whole lot can compel me to consider rereading, then maybe something's there. I'm not quite sure why this one, out of many other great contenders, achieved the Prinz. But, I'm also not on the committee :)

This is a Printz that I actually didn't hate with a burning passion - impressive. I liked the idea for this story, but at times I felt it was a little random, and I wasn't sure how things were going to add up at the end. The beginning was really weird and I was trying to adjust to how the story was moving along and keep track of all the characters. The backstory that was interwoven throughout was really intriguing and I kept reading because I wanted to know what had happened. The ending was unsuspecting, but still fulfilling. I wouldn't recommend this book to everyone because some of the content was objectionable and it wasn't as fast moving of a story as I would have liked. It had potential though, it just needed a little bit more tweaking to have made it a really good read.*Taken from my book reviews blog: http://reviewsatmse.blogspot.com/2009...

I'm torn between 3 and 4 stars. Started out confusing, then became predictable. Interesting story, if somewhat depressing. Seemed like no one was ever really happy in the story, at least not for long. Tragedy all around, and Taylor's narration showed her to be a serious, grumpy girl, yet everyone seemed to love her. Hmm. Ended on an optimistic note, so that helped.If I hadn't been so busy and tired lately it wouldn't have taken me so long to read this, and maybe I would have liked it more. But maybe not. The bad language threw me. I thought it was unnecessary and distracting, and made me like the characters less. Intriguing plot, though.
it really took me awhile to get into this one, very complicated plot- i felt like i need to start a character list, i would only recommend this one for the most avid teen readers

This one had to grow on me. I was confused and bored at first but by the end I couldn't not finish it. Marchetta, Melina Jellicoe Road 419 pgs. Harper Teen ~Language R, Sexual Content~R Violence~PG-13Jellicoe Road in Austrailia is the main character in this novel about finding who you are and the importance of family relationships. Taylor Markham, age seventeen, is the leader of a house of girls at a boarding school in Austrailia. Each Summer, the boarding school kids participate in territory wars with the Cadets (Summer camp attendees from the military academy in Sydney) and the Townies (kids from the local town.) The novel begins with a flash-back that grabs the reader’s attention immediately, however, when chapter 1 begins it is slightly disorienting and it takes a few pages for the reader to orient themselves in the world of Taylor. There is a mystery embedded in the narrative that may initially cause confusion among readers, but those who stick with the storyline will be highly rewarded. I personally had a hard time wanting to stay with the story but I loved how it all came together. This title won the Michael L. Printz award for 2009. There are 2 sex scenes that are descriptive and sensual but not highly graphic. The swearing is scattered throughout narrative and includes 10-15 “f” and several “a**.” I would recommend letting the public libraries house this one.HS NO Allison Madsen~Youth Services Librarian-SJO Public Librarian
why did this win?

Have you ever turned on the radio and its in the middle of a new song and you like the song for all the reasons you like music: rhythm, beat, lyrics, voice... but you really don't know what its about? like any of the songs from sgt.pepper, for example? so you want to listen to it again? That's what happened for me with Jellicoe Road. I think when i read it again, i will break with affection for these characters. First time though, i liked them amd felt for them, but i found it very challenging to map their live experiences and relationships; to the point of diminishing my appreciation for the story. an interestng reading experience.

This book had excellent plot lines. However, it was definitely a bit confusing switching from one to the next. There were also a lot of characters and with the different plot lines I was lost half the time. This must be a similarity of Australian authors. Taylor Markham is such a stong seventeen year old who has lived her fair share of tragedies. It is amazing she turns out as well as she does. I did like the ending of this book, but don't want to give it away so I'll just say it was very appropriate. The biggest appeal of Jellicoe Road lies in the settings, both past and present, and the vivid description of Jellicoe Road.I think this book may be a bit difficult for young adults, but who am I to say a child cannot handle a book? It just depends what each teen likes in books and if they can follow a confusing book, then I would recommend it to them! The characters are believable, but there are just so many of them to sort out. I would promote this book to teens when doing a unit on Australia. It is a rather historical book that mentions many cities and towns of Australia. To conclude, I understand why this book was nominated as a Printz Book, but it is rather confusing and it would not have received my vote. I encourage those who are interested to try it!4Q3PJ

This is a fascinating and unusual story about a young girl who lives at a private school in Australia. Years ago, several teens invented a game of "war," in which Townies and members of a military school compete for turf against her school. She has been chosen to lead her school in the next war. But she is also dealing with being abandoned first by her mother and then by her closest adult friend at the school. There is a connection between her and the original band of teens who began the war and as the novel progresses, she slowly unravels these connections. An intricate novel about surviving abandonment and forging new relationships.

I enjoyed this book. I hadn't heard much about it until it won the Printz award. The storyline is a bit confusing at times, but I enjoyed the story, the characters, and the setting. It was worth reading.

For me the book finally became interesting once the story started coming together (around the 200's), but I'm not sure if I ever really enjoyed reading it or felt connected to the characters. Maybe I'll pick it up again some day...

Just got the Printz Award. The first half of this book is very confusing. I think this reflects the confusion of the main character. As the story progresses all the disjointed and random bits of the story fall into place on tiny bit at a time. Ultimately the characters fall into their places, settling with the past and facing the future.

I rarely give out five stars, that is reserved for books that really, really catch me. Books that make me look at the world differently or that just speak to me on some level I wasn't expecting. Jellicoe Road did all three. This is a beautiful, haunting book and I know the characters will remain with me for a long time. The characters are what make this book shine and they are so well done! Marchetta creates characters that leap from the page and feel like friends you might have known in school. The descriptions are beautiful and lyrical. The pace is at times fast, at times leisurely and slow, but always moving forward with a sort of inevitability that does not feel forced or contrived. Taylor Markham is trying to unravel the secrets in her past, to find where her guardian has disappeared to. At the same time, the tale of five friends who met on the Jellicoe Road more than 20 years before unfolds along side Taylor's. As the two stories overlap and weave together the narratives combine into one remarkable, tragic and redemptive story that feels true and deep. This is definitely going on my permanent book shelf and will be read again.

Like many Goodreads readers, I was confused for at least the first half of this book. Although everything came together eventually, I feel like I never completely forgave the story for keeping me in the dark for so long. I also thought it was kind of strange that this was ostensibly a school story, yet the characters never seemed to go to class!

Good. Would be rated higher but much of the plot revolved around some pretty harsh situations. Taylor puts together puzzle pieces of her past and learns to love. The mystery of Taylor's past is skillfully revealed, bit by bit. Note to sensitive readers: some language and a couple of sex scenes.

Jellicoe Road would appeal to different kinds of teens, boys and girls. The main character is a seventeen year old girl named Taylor who was abandoned by her mother on the Jellicoe Road when she was ten. There is another story involving characters twenty years prior and gradually both stories connect to each other piece by piece, although it can be a bit confusing keeping all the characters straight. I would recommend this book to a teen who might be struggling with family/roots problems since Taylor can remember very little of her mother and father and is the main reason she is kind of closed off to everyone she meets. There is a rival between different groups in the community that would appeal to teens wanting to read about secret adventures grownups aren't aware of. I would give it a 4Q, a 3P, and would recommend it to teens J and S teens.

I liked this a lot, though I probably wouldn't have chosen it as the Printz winner over Nation and Tender Morsels, myself; I thought it got a little melodramatic. I'm glad I was warned that it wouldn't make any sense for [a varying but large number of pages:].

The problem with this book is that it just dragged on for some period there- it took a good 150 pages for me to be able to really get in the groove of the book. In the end it was a really touching story that I actually dreamt about for several days but I can't see many of my teens having the patience to get through the drab entrance to get to the meat of the story. I also found myself stumbling on the Australian slang and could have used footnotes or end notes in some cases.
A well thought out, intricately plotted novel. Everything is as planned out and beautiful as the road that guides the story through the years.Absolutely worth reading.

My rating reflects the kind of reader I have become. This novel is utterly confusing until you get deep into the plot. Once you really realize that there are two stories being told, Taylor's story of her the time when she meets Jonah and forms a deep relationship, and the second is the story of Webb, Tate, Narnie, Fitz and Jude whose lives are interwoven following a tragic accident on Jellicoe Road. What makes the story difficult to follow is the fact that it isn't written in a chronilogical format. The reader, if in a classroom setting, might benefit from keeping notes on the characters or a timeline of events in each character's life. I didn't realize until late in the story that Taylor would meet her mother again, which is the perfect ending to the most confusing story I've read. Making a family tree visual prior to reading in the classroom, would offer meaning for the reader of the families and the conflict that exists. Marchetta deals with so many themes, it will be a long study for the class who takes on this book. The students or the reader will be forced to think about family relationships and roles. The reader will see many examples of friendships, both good and bad, which will lead to issues of loyalty. I also wanted to know more about the parents of these children. What parenting roles are to be modeled or emulated and what parental roles would we like to broach and forget? Children are often forced, too soon, to deal with the harshness life can offer with death's grief and with the possibility of abandonment by parents for whatever reasons. This would be an incredible book to use in order to study relationships. I would have to recommend that the teacher read it several times so as not to miss the many messages twisted into the plot and to be able to guide the reader through the issues creatively. Not an easy read is Jellicoe Road, but a most challenging and interesting one. Still, it is not one I would just pick up for pleasure, I would have to have encouragement or pressure if I were a student today. These are relevant topics in the game of life that all adolescents should embrace. This book may be very difficult for the suffering kid. It wouldn't be possible for the struggling reader.5Q 3P S

UPDATED REVIEW FROM JULY 2009: After hearing Melina Marchetta's Printz Award acceptance speech at the ALA Annual Conference, I felt compelled to give it another try. While I still felt it took too long to feel attached to the characters, the story did eventually draw me in. I enjoyed the parallels that are drawn between Taylor and her group of friends (which includes Jellicoe students, Townies, and a Cadet) and Taylor's parents and their group of friends (which included Jellicoe students, a Townie, and a Cadet) and how Taylor learned about her family's history. A well-constructed plot and intriguing conflicts make for a compelling story, but the slow build-up is likely to make this a tough sell for most teens.---------INITIAL REVIEW FROM MARCH 2009:Okay... to be honest, I didn't finish this book. I didn't even get past Chapter 6. But I tried to WANT to read it for almost two weeks before finally giving up today. I'm sure the Printz Award Committee had their reasons for selecting it for this year's winner, but I just couldn't get into the story. I didn't feel any connection to the main character, or any of the characters really, and I wasn't even really intrigued by the "mystery" of how the territory wars began. I tried. I really did. It was just a no-go for me.

I liked the writing. The story was interesting. I got tired of the "f" word used so often. There was a very cavalier attitude about teen sex and teen pregnancy. This book was heartbreaking in many spots, but I liked that the characters tried to look out for each other. There was a sweetness and innocence to the characters that I enjoyed. When the two main characters, Taylor and Griggs, had sex I was very disappointed and felt Taylor was making the same mistakes her mother made--too much commitment too young. I wish she had made a better choice. Teens deserve better morals in their literature. The story was compelling, though.

What a strange trip this book was. It rings like a bell somehow. There's some mystery not uncolored with horror, and some fabulous characterization. The plot arc is clean and relatively taut. On the other hand, there are some holes big enough to drive a postal van through. It's a book that communicates directly with the dark places in one's subconscious, one that has layers of meaning that have little to do with extraneous plot details. Disturbing and haunting. I'm glad I read it, but I'm not sure about the repercussions of its reverberations.
It was too dis-jointed for me--strong ending, but I really had to push to keep reading.

Just like The Disreputable History of Frankie Landau-Banks, I just don't get why this won the Printz Award (I know, I know- the former was an Honor award). Oh yeah, it has orphans... It was good, but it took a long time to get into it. Might appeal to a few mature, female young adults.

This is the 2009 Printz Award, the Teen equivalent of the Newbery Award. It was published in Australia a couple of years ago and was published last year in the U.S. Well, I must say, the Aussies are becoming my new favorite group of authors (Zusak, Shusterman, to name two). I loved the voice and the story kept me very intrigued, but my rating is a little lower than it could have been because as I was reading, I kept hearing my daughter's constant criticism of teen books that adults love. I teased her when I was reading it, saying, "You'll love this book." She responded as sarcastically as I asked, "Why because it's full of dysfunctional families, drugs and missing mothers." "Exactly!" That's basically what this book is about, but, to its credit, it is well done and has an element of mystery to it. It is about 5 friends who lived near Jellicoe Road years ago contrasted with a group of students, townies, and cadets who live there now. Their stories become connected and over time, the obscure passages told from the past become more and more clear. It definitely kept me turning the pages.
It was a good mystery, but not entirely satisfying to me. Review on my blog: http://librariansbookreviews.blogspot...

A good one but a bit difficult to follow at times. Much better than last year's Printz winner but I still think they could choose books that were a little more accessible to the general teen population - I think this wouldn't work for most readers.
The Printz Medal winner 2009. The plot is confusing at first because it has 2 intertwining stories that end up being the same story. I was totally confused through about the first half of the book.
A little too dramatic for me, but a good read. The insight of the girl was good, but the drama just keeps going until the end.

It took me forever to read this book (because it kept getting interrupted by others I had to read), so I feel a little disconnected from it for that reason. Our heroine Taylor is tough, a bit prickly, and yet vulnerable. Honestly, what kept me going was the mystery surrounding her intense relationship with her should-be enemy, Jonah Griggs. I found the side-plot/interruptions by Hannah's writing to be a tad annoying and yet compelling. I kept forgetting the second story's characters, and when I was just wanting to read about Taylor, the damn second plot would interrupt. So, despite the fact that I just rattled off things I dislike, I thought the book was interesting with good characters. Definitely would NOT have given the Printz to this book over Hunger Games--TRAVESTY!

Sorry JB, but this book DID NOT deserve to win the Printz. Not when it was up against Tender Morsels, Octavian Nothing: Kingdom on the Waves, and The Disreptuable History of Frankie Landau-Banks (which should have won instead). Jellicoe Road is beautifully written, and the characters are well-drawn and full of life, BUT it was full of way too many realistic teen fiction cliches (abandoned teens, boarding school skirmishes, ultimate romance between bitter rivals, and so on). Also, the connections between the past and present narratives become apparent pretty early on, and then the plot becomes rather predictable. It was a good book, and I don't regret reading it, but it didn't blow me away like Frankie Landau-Banks did.

The writing is a little confusing at first. The voice switches from a story written by a character to another character's perspective. I liked the story plot; it seemed a little far fetched at times. The main character is extremely likable and has the moody teenager thing down perfectly. I am not sure that it is so wonderful that it is a must read for teenagers.

I picked up this book after learning it won the Newbery Award for young adult fiction this year. It was a mixed bag. The first half was too all over the place, introducing too many characters and not focusing enough on Taylor (the main character), consequently I didn't really "care" about what happened to her. Things really shaped up in the second half, Marchetta got more into the character development and the story sucked me in. By the end of the book, I was a fan. : )

A group of teens bond while partaking in a cruel tradition of territory wars between boarding schoolers, townies, and visiting cadets. Eventually the story of the first teens who devised these "games" is uncovered, providing answers which help heal protagonist Taylor's shattered life. (But Taylor suffers tremendously due to a lot of seemingly unnecessary secrecy about her past! And why isn't she getting counseling?!!) Marchetta's writing is described as "heartfelt" on the dust jacket. Sure, there is love and redemption, but the story's violence, angst and unlawfulness overshadowed that for me, and I still feel raw from it all. (Why couldn't the cat have been painlessly euthanized? Why did Ben's fingers have to be broken? Why the whole fire scene, and the jocular attitude about arson?) After also reading "The Chocolate War", "Catcher in the Rye", and "Looking for Alaska" all in the past year, I've had my full share of boarding school hell, but I forced myself to read past the first few chapters of "On the Jellicoe Road" because this book received the Printz Award--I wanted to find its merits. I personally did not enjoy the edgy tone, but the story's layers of narrative are indeed cleverly wrought. The suspense is gripping, the friendships memorable. And there are probably deeper themes about Australia that elude me. The original gang of five (as well as Taylor's new group of friends) can represent the different cultural ancestry of Australia--their pain, warfare and friendships represent the nation's history and its hope. In that way, I would also compare this book to "A Separate Peace", one that I could not fully understand and appreciate as a teen until it was carefully taught in school. This book, however, is much more graphic.

This was different from most things that I read, and it took me awhile to get into it, but in the end, it was a decent read.Warning for those who object to rough language -- this one uses some offensive language.

I had a hard time getting into this book. I couldn't get into the school/campus wars. The best part of the book was Narnie's stories. I would have like to have more Narnie, Webb, Tate, Jude, and Fitz. I pushed through. I was anxious to see how Taylor's life was connected to those 5.The ending was well worth the wait. It was filled with love, emotion, and loads of togetherness. Would I recommend? Only if you can hold off until about 100-150 pages. It doesn't start to get interesting until then. (Looking at other reviews, I don't seem to be alone in this.) The ending is definitely worth the wait.

Taylor is the head of her house at the Jellicoe boarding school and she’s the head of the school in the territory wars between the school, the Townies, and the Cadets. Taylor ran away from school 3 years ago when she was 14 (with one of the Cadets – Jonah Griggs) to try and find her mother who abandoned her at a 7-11 when she was just a little girl. Taylor’s been wondering about her family and her past for as long as she can remember, and this year things come to a head when her guardian, Hannah, disappears for several weeks to take care of some “personal” business, and leaves Taylor alone and frustrated. Taylor and the leaders of the Cadets and Townies become close friends, as the leaders once were back when the territory wars started. And it’s Jonah, again, who accompanies Taylor when she sets off – this time to track down Hannah – in search of the truth.This is really two stories woven together - Hannah’s story about her past, and Taylor’s story about her present. They’re remarkably similar – with young people who come to be friends and then more than friends, who invent and play a game just so they can spend more time together, and who have a shared history. In Hannah’s story, however, there’s a terrible tragedy that affects the lives of all the others and continues to have effects years later. It’s what makes Taylor’s mom turn to drugs so she can forget, what makes her abandon Taylor, what makes Hannah keep a distance from the people she loves, and what eventually brings the survivors back together again. This is all about the friendships forged and the unraveling mystery of Taylor’s and Hannah’s past. I really like Melina Marchetta’s writing, she creates realistic characters and situations and stories with depth.

Marchetta captures the complexity of human relationships in a way that is compelling and and memorable.Due to the language and subject matter, this book would be best for mature teens or adults--preferrably to read and discuss together.

Yep everyone right, this one was slightly confusing for the first hundred pages or so. I kept wondering if that was the authors way of creating some mystery because, while I really liked the book, it was pretty obvious what was going on and who was who. I loved the relationships, and since that's primarily what the book was about, I enjoyed it.
For the first forty pages I was really confused about what was going on. Then it was okay

I found the beginning of this book confusing and hard to get into, but after the first seventy pages or so, it sucked me in and it haunted me for a couple days after I finished. You know a book's written well, when it stays with you like that after you put it down. I just wish the beginning was easier to wade through.
By the end of this book I was really engrossed, but it took awhile. The interaction between the two stories was intriguing.

It's a good read and nicely constructed, but the amount of barely contained emotion in this book made me tired after about 200 pages. The narrative voice is very cool and restrained, so it didn't quite veer off into melodrama, but sometimes I wished there had been more quiet and ordinary things going on in between the characters' intense revelations of family and personal history. And I got skeptical sometimes about all the caring being directed at Taylor. All the right people care about each other and seem much too emotionally fluent for people who have supposedly suffered so much damage throughout their lives. But it's a sweet story, if you're willing to suspend your disbelief a little. And the second to last page did give me chills, a bit.

Had to move on. I kept putting it down and picking it up again because it won the Printz this year, and the reviewers said it comes together really well. I love complex stories, generally, and want to see how Hannah's story comes together with Taylors. I love the Australian authors, and I loved Marchetta's Saving Francesca. So, this has a lot going for it, but I think I'm just not in the mood right now. Recommended for high school.

Although I really liked the last 1/4 of the book, it took me a long time to get into this book. I am sure I missed a lot of stuff at the beginning because I was confused. Perhaps if I read the book again I would like it more. I don't know many teens who would stick with this book...I think many would start it and never finish it. I'll have to read more reviews to figure out why it won the Printz!

I have had this book for a week and I am only on Chapter 3. It's sort of painful right now and I am considering ditching it. Someone, tell me if I should keep going.Ok so now I'm done and although I can't say anything negative about it (interesting characters, exciting and surprising plot, original setting) I just wasn't wowed personally. I think it was all the territory wars, which I tried really hard to care about since it made sense to me why territory was so important to these kids, but I just couldn't care enough. It's akin to how I feel about the game Risk. I appreciate the game and understand why it's so popular, but do I want to play? Not really.I will be recommending this book a lot, though. I think it will rock a lot of folks' socks.
Although slow to begin, I found myself invested in the lives of Taylor and her 'family'.

I really hated this book at the beginning but kept going since Kate had liked it. And I ended up enjoying it quite a bit. The author is Australian which is funny because the book reminded me a bit of a Markus Zusak book and he is the only other YA Australian author that I know. Maybe they are all the same over there...

This year's Printz Award winner for young adults. What a wonderful, complex book! A little slow to begin with, but worth the effort. This is an amazing book that is set in Australia. From the beginning, you are introduced to five friends, who stick by each other through trials and terrible tragedies. Interwoven into the five characters (they are from the past), you also learn about a group of young friends, present time period, who are going through their own set of troubles. As the story progresses, the author does an amazing job of bringing past with present for a terrific ending.

I thought this book was a bit strange. I know it is intended for young readers, but I can't recommend it because of the violence, language, and values. Once I got into the story it was OK, but I was taken aback everytime I got to one of those "spots" in the story. I am not offended easily and I know the book won an award, but this is not for kids. It is an OK read for adults though and the writing is well done.

There's something that resonates with me in this story. The hopes and fears that Taylor feels toward the people in her life are things I think most people can identify with and understand. Plus, on a less serious note anything that makes me cry my own tears has to get at least 3-stars. And not to be a Debbie Downer, but sometimes the unnecessarily "inscrutable, secretive, reticent, evasive, furtive" characters masquerading around under the pretense of something mysterioso wasn't impressive.
this book was okay, kind of confusing at first though....
You must be willing to read 200 pages of "whatever" before the story gets rolling. Liked it a lot BUT, it was disjointed.

I ripped right through this book and really did like it, but I found the organization really confusing in the first half of the book and way too predictable in the second half. I figured out all of the "subtle" connections between the characters quite a bit before the main character realized them and so was a bit bored while she fumbled along for another 100 pages. That said, the general plot and characters are really interesting and, for the most part, make up for the book's weaknesses.

Beware spoilers ahead.Well, hmm. There were parts of this book I found just wonderful -- in particular, Melina Marchetta does teenagers shooting the breeze and falling in love, the multiple layers of that dialogue and how it can be both understatedly casual and completely overwhelmingly meaningful and intense at the same time, better than anyone I know. I loved Taylor's relationship with Griggs, I loved the territory wars (once I figured out they were just a game and not some postapocalyptic serious thing), all the school stuff was great. But the family piece felt willfully obscure to me, and also sort of willfully irrational or melodramatic. Like, WHY wouldn't Hannah tell Taylor she was her aunt? She could do that without undermining her relationship with her mother, it seemed to me -- indeed, it might even clarify the Hannah-Taylor relationship by better defining the roles. Or why wouldn't she tell Taylor about her dad, her beloved brother? Did Taylor not know her mom's first name was Tate? The Hermit was Fitz, and he shot himself because he felt guilty about shooting Webb, right? And he did it in front of Taylor because she reminded him so much of Webb?Everyone says this is better the second time through, and I can believe that, and I guess I should go back and reread it. But the first read left me so nonplussed about all this that I don't really want to spend the eye time on the second read. It was okay, but I didn't love it.

VOYA Book Review Code: S, A/YA; 2P; 3QI thought Jellicoe Road by Melina Marchetta was a pretty intense story. I did not really know what to expect from this book and at times I found it difficult to read, but as I continued I got more and more into it. Jellicoe Road is a book for females, but I’m glad I had an opportunity to read it.
Well done - can definitely see why this was an award winner. Really enjoyed the narrative structure!
Really hard to get into, but worth plowing through the first 150 pages

Maybe a 3.5?I did enjoy this book and for once all the teens in the book actually had reasons to be dramatic. In the end I really did love the story, though it was very sad and tragic in parts. The reason this book wasn't a 4 or 5 star book for me was in the way the plot is set up. At the beginning I found it very confusing. A story told in italics, a bitchy, hateful teenager, and a weird Skulls-esque secret society who are fighting a turf war with no purpose. It took a while for the plot to sort itself out and to get me to care about all the characters, though I did by the end. I also thought there was too much foreshadowing, so by the time Taylor makes her revelations, it's not shocking, it's something that I've figured out chapters before. At the beginning it seemed like that was the point: that Taylor really know the truth but doesn't want to say it aloud, and won't admit she knows until it's completely obvious. I'm not sure if that's what the author intended though.I didn't like the climax. It seemed over the top like the author wanted a big gesture to get her point across, but it made me skeptical (like of course that would happen) especially when the real cause came out. Disappointing, but once all that was over I loved the actual ending. So by the end it all came together and made sense. However, it took too long to get there, and I can understand people giving up on the book before they finish. Definitely don't think it should have won the Printz (I think Hunger Games was better) but it did deal with some tough issues really well. I would still definitely recommend it, but a little editing would have made it better.
I think I'm just not a YA person. Not much of one, anyway.
It was okay. REALLY confusing for the first 100-150 pages but once you get it you're pretty hooked. And the end tied everything together in a fun way. Very tricky.

Taylor Markham was eleven when her mother left her at a 7-11 in the Australian countryside. She's spent the last six years at a school, keeping her distance from everyone except Hannah, a woman who has a house off the school's property.When Hannah disappears at the same time as a couple of local children, rumors begin to circulate that the area serial killer has re-emerged. To add to her problems, Taylor finds herself leading a team of students in the annual territory wars between the school, Cadets and Townies.A coming-of-age story with a twist, Jellicoe Road explores the idea of finding yourself by learning about your past and your family's history --however horrific and tragic it may be.
I liked this book.

This book was utterly confusing for the first 100-150 pages. If I hadn't been reading it for book club I probably would have stopped. But then I would have missed a beautiful ending.On a side note, there wasn't much bad language and sex, but for a "teen" book I would prefer there wan't any.

Cons: the distracting language. Pros: great character development and fascinating mystery.Like many other reviewers, I had a hard time figuring out what was going on for the first half of the book. However, it comes together well in the end. I loved the mystery and I think I'll have to read it again. I'll probably like it more without all the opening confusion.

When I first picked this book up I had the hardest time getting into it so I jumped onto goodreads to check the reviews. Everyone that really enjoyed it said to just power through the first 150 pages and then it'll start to make sense. That was really hard for me cause I hate reading something and wondering if I'm missing the important parts. This was a really interestingly crafted story that provides history of the characters and flashback dreams and chaos all at the same time. The end was a little anti climatic for me after so much work to get to it, but I bet if you have time to read it a second time you'll appreciate it more.
A coming of age novel ripe with an everpresent war between the various teenagers along the Jellicoe Road that was set up by past events. Wonderful descriptions.

This is an American Library Assoc. Printz Award for Excellence in Young Adult Lit, so you have to respect that. It was a little slow at first, but it did get better. It's pretty cool how all these mysterious pieces of the plot fit together in the end.

I know this is an award winner. But that award was given by adult who are librarians and are going to read it all the way through. Few teens are going to have the patience to do that. Note all the comments here about "it took a while for me to get into this...the first half is slow....not enough happens at first...." etc? Do you really think that the average reader of crap like "Twilight" is going to have the same patience as a bright young Childrens/YA librarian--or a cranky older one? :DThere is too much going on here. There's the war between the schools story, there's Taylor's back story, there's the Narnie story. It's confusing and jerky. Eventually, they all come together and the ending will satisfy by making (nearly) everything come out happily ever after--a bit of a stretch for me, but great for those teens, if they get there.And I don't think that they will.
Once I got past the confusing part, it was completely predictable. Still, it was an interesting story and I liked the characters.Click here for my full review.

Told from the perspective of a 17-year old Australian young woman at a boarding school, this book offers another story within it about a special group of friends who are brought together due to a horrific car accident. A good, fast coming-of-age story.

I enjoy stories woven together - multiple threads that seem unrelated tied back into a lovely pattern. This book is more like a Rauschenberg painting - at first there is a sense of chaos, of story lines that you know MUST be related (they are in the same book after all) but its not tidy, like a tapestry where the picture starts to become clearer as its woven. The longer you look at a Rauschenberg painting, though, the more you can see pattern and even a cohesive theme. There are themes of abandonment, mixed with love and hope, of learning about the frailties of one's parents (who are human and have a past that does not include you), of discovering a history you belong to. My favorite idea what put into two statements: "Belong. Longing to be."

This book is quite interesting, and definitely a mystery. It was fun to try to figure out who was who. I love when characters form good friendships, and especially when there's a special connection. That happens between the two main characters, and a little with a few others. I wouldn't recommend it for 7th and 8th graders.

i liked this best and was in 5-star love mode when the territory wars drove the narrative and the past/present/taylor/hannah/5 kids stuff seethed right below the surface. when the past/present/taylor/hannah/5 kids stuff was the sole focus though... it was just too... schmaltzy.

The first half of this book was very boring and typical, in my opinion. I would only give that section about one or two stars, as I was forcing myself to read it (it was the only book I brought on a plane). The second half was incredibly good. I would rank that part about 4 or 5 stars for its characterization, interest level, and suspense. Therefore, I averaged the two, and gave it 3 stars.

Taylor Markham was abandoned on the Jellicoe Road when she was eleven. At seventeen she attends the Jellicoe School, where 10% of the students are also wards of the state, like her. It's convenient for Taylor, whose caretaker, Hannah, lives right outside school property. At the beginning of her senior year, she finds herself elected not only leader of her dorm, but leader of all the Jellicoe dorms in the Territory Wars in which her school, the Townies and the Cadets (who camp in the local bushland every year) participate. The rules have been passed down year after year in a purple notebook, and Taylor is under pressure to make sure things go smoothly for Jellicoe. However, just as things are getting underway, Hannah leaves without notice, and Taylor's life is in turmoil. She discovers that the manuscript of Hannah's that she's been reading over the years might be more than just a story, and she discovers that the Cadet she claims to have no history with might be more than just a one-time acquaintance. As the leaders of the various groups get closer through the War, they find that there is more to their game than they ever thought, and Taylor discovers that her family history is more complicated and bittersweet than she'd ever imagined.Marchetta's book is beautiful, but stricken with slow pacing that may not catch the attention of many readers. While the snippets of Hannah's manuscript and the peeks at romance certainly make things interesting, the plot doesn't pick up until at least half way through the book, and the Territory Wars are confusing at best until the very end. This is a book that I would certainly recommend to teen readers, but not without the caveat that they really need to stick with it to get to the good parts.
A good book, no real surprises and not very thought provoking.

This Australian young adult title won the Printz Award which is given to the best YA book published in the U.S. in a given year. So, of course, I had to read it to see what the fuss was about. I know from reading other librarians' blogs that this winner came out of left field. And I have to agree with them. To me, this title is a lot like The Book Thief. It's a mature book, but not because it's full of "adult" topics. It's written like an adult book--flashbacks, lots of secondary characters, and winding plots and innuendos.[return][return]I had to force myself to finish it. I didn't get sucked into the book until the last third of it, when I had to stay up until 1 am to finish. However, I don't think my teenagers will enjoy it. It's another boarding school book and the mystery doesn't grab the reader like it should. The italicized flashbacks are confusing until the readers gets to the last third of the book. I never really liked the main character, either, although she does seem witty. I didn't want to feel sorry for her because she isn't nice to her housemates. And when she finally was a good friend, I thought her actions seemed forced.

When I first started this book, I was tempted to put it down. The beginning was confusing and not very interesting. But, I read the reviews on Goodreads - plus, it won the Printz award, so I felt sort of obliged to read it - and many of them said the same thing: keep reading, the end is worth it. And it is. The problem is, I don't think many teens are willing to wade through 100+ pages of a book before the story starts to make sense or gets really interesting. Like many other award winners, this story has orphans (why are there always orphans?), and similar to some other Printz award and honor books(Frankie Landau-Banks, Looking for Alaska), this story takes place at a boarding school (I wonder how many teens can relate to living at a boarding school?). At any rate, if you've got a teen who is a very mature and patient reader, you might recommend this to them. There are two sex scenes (very mild, not graphic), and a good amount of cursing, so you might want to consider that when making recommendations. For high school and up.
I feel badly, bc I really wanted to like this book, but I just couldn't relate to the main character at all... she just seemed too sullen and put-upon...

About halfway through, I still wasn't quite sure why this won all the awards and accolades. But I stuck with it. It was a bit painful at times to try and piece together all the past and present characters, none of whom really came to life for me.
Liked it for the language and emotional tug, not the plot.

Interesting story, started slow but kind of clicked about a third of the of the way in. Was a page turner after that. I enjoyed it but had trouble forgiving the characters for their lack of communication, and had trouble forgiving the author for using the confusion of characters not communicating as the suspense in the novel. That might be a little harsh.

I don't know why so many people think this is so confusing to start. I thought the direction was kind of obvious. It's an ok book. Sorry, I suck at review writing. LoL It's a good character... who you can't help but feel for. The only thing that kind of didn't fit for me was the age of the characters. They are engaging in territory wars with eachother... something eleven year olds might do. And they often conduct themselves as such. The importance with which they treat the "war" really conveys that they should be small kids. However, they are in fact seventeen years old! (not all of them, but the main characters)... Maybe I'm jaded... but that seemed stupid.

Tortured souls at their best:"I remember love. It's what I have to keep myself. It's funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that's why humans find it so hard getting love affairs. It's not the pain they're getting over, It's the love."You have to invest in this book to really get something out of it. The author tries a bit too hard to weave two stories together. I almost stopped reading it, but the ending was redemptive and beautiful and tragic. The best kind of story.

Sigh... I really liked the writing style of this author, and I really liked so much of this story, I really liked this book, and I really wanted to use this for book club ----but---- it had a dark tone (a lot of horrible experiences and some graphic detail about accidents/suicide) and there was a lot of profanity (F-word filled up more than one hand) and all this in a book written for teens?! I would not let my daughters read this until they were much older(18). I am so torn because I liked this story SO much, yet the few things that I didn't like make it difficult to recommend to those who have my same standards, that said. it was a really good story.
Rating: 2.5

This book was rather hard to finish. I think that it was because of the flashback dialogue that kept popping up intermitently. It begins like this:"What do you want from me?" he asks. What I want from every person in my life, I want to tell him. More. Abandoned by her mother on Jellicoe Road when she was eleven, Taylor Markham, now seventeen, is finally being confronted with her past. But as the reluctant leader of her boarding school dorm, there isn't a lot of time for introspection. And while Hannah, the closest adult Taylor has to family, has disappeared, Jonah Griggs is back in town, moody stares and all. In this absorbing story by Melina Marchetta, nothing is as it seems and every clue leads to more questions as Taylor tries to work out the connection between her mother dumping her, Hannah finding her then and her sudden departure now, a mysterious stranger who once whispered something in her ear, a boy in her dreams, five kids who lived on Jellicoe Road eighteen years ago, and the maddening and magnetic Jonah Griggs, who knows her better than she thinks he does. If Taylor can put together the pieces of her past, she might just be able to change her future. Some students might enjoy the book as it deals with initiations and cliques. I don't think that I could get through it again although I am sure that it help me garner more understanding of what was going on.
Last comment was: I'm on page 106 of Jellicoe Road. not what I expected; definitely interesting; still wondering where it's going...... and I never got back to it! Didn't hate it, didn't love it...

This book was VERY slow to get started but once it got going it was pretty good. You really have to read it in one sitting or you get confused about what's going on. I kind of want to read it again to see what I missed, but I don't have a lot of free time and it wasn't good enough for me to make time to read it again. Would someone please tell me how she figured out that he was shot out of a tree by his friend?
Frustratingly unsatisfying until at least midway through, this book eventually offers a reward, but only after an exasperating journey.

Taylor was abandoned by her mother when she was eleven at a 7-11. She remembers being loved once and that is what keeps her going. Now, seventeen she has been given the job of leading her school against the Townies and the Cadets from Sydney (that make camp every year near their school). The war has been going on so long that nobody knew why it ever started. The purple book of the rules is all they have to go by and a rumor of a hidden tunnel that leads from Jellicoe School to the town. Taylor, now leader of the Jellicoe School students, is questioned by each leader of the other houses. Her past has come back to haunt her, just as the one person who has been constant in her life, Hannah, disappears. The Cadet she ran away with when she was younger (who later turned her in) has come back to town to lead the Cadets. Taylor’s life is difficult but she must find a way to protect and expand her schools territory, find her mother and Hannah, discover the truth about how the war really started and where she really comes from, and finally find herself and where she belongs.I’m more of a fantasy person, but I really enjoyed this. I tend to love her books when I read them.

I had to read it for class, and it was the second school book that I ever enjoyed. Yeah, it was dull and depressing, but compared to the other stuff they make me read it was a breath of fresh, tropical air. The characters are interesting, if a little too mysterious and obnoxious for my liking. The plot was well structured and I liked how the story came full circle. It had the odd effect of being encouraging despite all the death and sadness. I suppose I would recommend it.

For some reason I feel inexplicably guilty about giving this book three stars. Although it won the Printz and a plethora of other awards I just can not board the bandwagon. I admit I had high expectations even before starting the book, but it disappointed me still.The beginning of Jellicoe Road had me confused - it set up the rest of the story, but I could not get over the initial confusion and therefore did not enjoy all of the events that occurred later on. I felt disconnected from the characters, too. There were a few heartwarming moments between Taylor, Jonah, and Hannah, but I did not empathize with them as much as I would have liked to.Overall, I would recommend reading Jellicoe Road. The first 150 pages made my head spin, but it got better.
What started out as a bizarre little book actually turned out to be pretty cool .

3.5 starsI know this is a book that everyone gives 5 stars. And it's hard for me to know that, and know that it's a Printz winner, and not give it 5 stars myself. But I just couldn't connect with this book. I actually gave up on it, and only picked it up again at the urging of a few friends. The writing is absolutely amazing. I would definitely pick up something else by the author because her writing is wonderful. But the long slog to get to the plot in the beginning, and then the ultimate pay-off, was just too confusing and not worth it. I thought many of the plot points didn't seem to match character motivations, and I wasn't sure why characters were acting that way. I also guessed a few of the issues that were supposed to be surprises. That being said, a lot of the story was compelling and drew me in. I liked how the relationship between the two main characters played out, and I thought Taylor's growth was wonderful. Ultimately, though, I didn't LOVE the book.

This book was kind of confusing in the beginning since it wasn't in chronological order and followed different characters, but when it all came together towards the end, I couldn't stop reading it! It had to deal with friendship, love, and all the craziness that deals with our fallen nature.
Well written story of growing up and friendships.A few things I don't agree with as presented, but a good read.
